Taravangian

text.content: is probably my favorite character of all time.

rich_text.plain_text: is probably my favorite character of all time.

text.content: For those (*cough plebs) who don‚Äôt know, he exists in the Cosmere - Brandon Sanderson‚Äôs universe - and suffers from a novel, yet oddly relatable, curse.

rich_text.plain_text: For those (*cough plebs) who don‚Äôt know, he exists in the Cosmere - Brandon Sanderson‚Äôs universe - and suffers from a novel, yet oddly relatable, curse.

text.content: Simply put, he is blessed with

rich_text.plain_text: Simply put, he is blessed with

text.content: capacity.

rich_text.plain_text: capacity.

text.content: Capacity for overwhelming intelligence or boundless compassion, but never both simultaneously. And here‚Äôs the rub - each day of his life he is dealt a different hand. His intelligence varies wildly from absent on one day to transcendant, even god-like, on another.

rich_text.plain_text: Capacity for overwhelming intelligence or boundless compassion, but never both simultaneously. And here‚Äôs the rub - each day of his life he is dealt a different hand. His intelligence varies wildly from absent on one day to transcendant, even god-like, on another.

text.content: When I call this relatable, I am not implying that I‚Äôm a genius. But I do feel like my own intelligence, on any given day, lies somewhere on a frustratingly wide spectrum. Some days I feel brilliant, bold, and confident in the connections my mind forms. Other days, I feel a latency to my thoughts that annoys me to no end. I hate that feeling, that I can‚Äôt articulate my thoughts or succinctly answer someone‚Äôs questions.

text.content: folder üôè. The wrappers, decorators, props, dependencies, and type declarations fill them simultaneously with wonder and imposter syndrome. Surely, they could never write code like this. I won‚Äôt sugercoat it‚Ä¶ most often, their code is miles beyond what your paltry GitHub offerings might be. I know they exceed my own. But until we take the learn to truly understand how things work, we will live in fear. I hope that by posting my methods here, I will feel pressured to dive a little deeper and answer the questions that could otherwise be brushed off.

text.content: . I‚Äôve built plenty of apps now. Written a lot of üí© code. Solved plenty of real-world business problems through my job. Not claiming to be na, but I suspect that I‚Äôll never even feel competent if I don‚Äôt monitor my progress. My final goal in posting here is that I can observe the problems I have understood ‚Äî and solved ‚Äî and believe in myself through the precedent I have set.

text.content: My thoughts and takeaways from working in Oracle‚Äôs Netsuite ERP

text.content: netsuite-first-impressions

text.content: Oracle‚Äôs Netsuite: 2 Months of Shameless, Self-Guided Reverse Engineering

title.plain_text: Oracle‚Äôs Netsuite: 2 Months of Shameless, Self-Guided Reverse Engineering

text.content: 10,000 ft view

rich_text.plain_text: 10,000 ft view

text.content: This is a great piece of code to study as a newer-than-many-if-not-most software engineer such as myself. Examples, good and bad, abound in this product, making work interesting and educational on most days. I‚Äôll use this article as an opportunity to explore some thoughts, and write down the stuff I might want to remember later.

rich_text.plain_text: This is a great piece of code to study as a newer-than-many-if-not-most software engineer such as myself. Examples, good and bad, abound in this product, making work interesting and educational on most days. I‚Äôll use this article as an opportunity to explore some thoughts, and write down the stuff I might want to remember later.

text.content: Why am I here?

rich_text.plain_text: Why am I here?

text.content: As a college student and an aspiring 10x senior software engineer, I find myself drawn to complex systems like NetSuite. Joking of course, I started working with it out of necessity.

rich_text.plain_text: As a college student and an aspiring 10x senior software engineer, I find myself drawn to complex systems like NetSuite. Joking of course, I started working with it out of necessity.

text.content: I currently work part-time at a mid-size finance company that manages their books, employee records, and transaction data in Netsuite. Alas, they are short on staff that are capable of scripting and connecting various systems together, which is where I come in. I have started to transplant Advanced Customer support. For better or worse, my customizations have made me familiar with the tool and the in-house technical consultant for the product.

rich_text.plain_text: I currently work part-time at a mid-size finance company that manages their books, employee records, and transaction data in Netsuite. Alas, they are short on staff that are capable of scripting and connecting various systems together, which is where I come in. I have started to transplant Advanced Customer support. For better or worse, my customizations have made me familiar with the tool and the in-house technical consultant for the product.

text.content: What is NetSuite?

rich_text.plain_text: What is NetSuite?

text.content: At its core, NetSuite is a cloud-based ERP system that helps businesses manage everything from finances to customer relationships. It‚Äôs a massive tool, and because of its scale, it‚Äôs easy to get lost in the thousands of features and configurations. Customizations are generally best avoided, but in my case, what‚Äôs done is done - my company began tweaking settings years ago. I‚Äôm just here to keep things in one piece. And if you know JavaScript and SQL, you have pretty much everything you need to pop the hood and get tweaking.

rich_text.plain_text: At its core, NetSuite is a cloud-based ERP system that helps businesses manage everything from finances to customer relationships. It‚Äôs a massive tool, and because of its scale, it‚Äôs easy to get lost in the thousands of features and configurations. Customizations are generally best avoided, but in my case, what‚Äôs done is done - my company began tweaking settings years ago. I‚Äôm just here to keep things in one piece. And if you know JavaScript and SQL, you have pretty much everything you need to pop the hood and get tweaking.

text.content: The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly

rich_text.plain_text: The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly

text.content: The Good:

rich_text.plain_text: The Good:

text.content: Learning Opportunities:

rich_text.plain_text: Learning Opportunities:

text.content: ¬†The depth of NetSuite offers endless opportunities to explore different aspects of software engineering. I‚Äôve already taken a deep dive into database design and have absolutely loved building tools that people actually use on the daily. Feels good to know my code is finally doing more than taking up memory.

rich_text.plain_text: ¬†The depth of NetSuite offers endless opportunities to explore different aspects of software engineering. I‚Äôve already taken a deep dive into database design and have absolutely loved building tools that people actually use on the daily. Feels good to know my code is finally doing more than taking up memory.

text.content: The Debugger:

rich_text.plain_text: The Debugger:

text.content: I love the variety of script types that are available for use. Each project that allows me to learn a new paradigm is a welcome challenge. But my favorites are the scripts that play nice with the debugger. There is something so satisfying about ad hoc debugging in Netsuite. Knowing that I can query underlying systems and piece together estranged records in seconds (blowing the frontend UI out of the water) is a blast. When you‚Äôre trying to wrap something so big with buttons and drop-downs, you end up creating more complexity than what you were trying to solve. Interacting with objects and prototypes directly is a breath of fresh air.

rich_text.plain_text: I love the variety of script types that are available for use. Each project that allows me to learn a new paradigm is a welcome challenge. But my favorites are the scripts that play nice with the debugger. There is something so satisfying about ad hoc debugging in Netsuite. Knowing that I can query underlying systems and piece together estranged records in seconds (blowing the frontend UI out of the water) is a blast. When you‚Äôre trying to wrap something so big with buttons and drop-downs, you end up creating more complexity than what you were trying to solve. Interacting with objects and prototypes directly is a breath of fresh air.

text.content: The Bad:

rich_text.plain_text: The Bad:

text.content: Documentation:

rich_text.plain_text: Documentation:

text.content: ¬†One of the things that can really blow a hole through your enthusiasm is the scattered, outdated, misleading, or otherwise unhelpful documentation that‚Äôs out there. There‚Äôs some good stuff, sure, but boy is there some bad.

rich_text.plain_text: ¬†One of the things that can really blow a hole through your enthusiasm is the scattered, outdated, misleading, or otherwise unhelpful documentation that‚Äôs out there. There‚Äôs some good stuff, sure, but boy is there some bad.

text.content: The Ugly:

rich_text.plain_text: The Ugly:

text.content: Legacy Code:

rich_text.plain_text: Legacy Code:

text.content: ¬†NetSuite has been around for a while, so there‚Äôs plenty of legacy code. Although aggravating for the truly experienced, I find studying it to be valuable. Like a glimpse of code from a bygone era. The OOP principles are so present, not yet abstracted to the point of dependency pasta. If only I didn‚Äôt have to write my own date conversion functions üò¢

rich_text.plain_text: ¬†NetSuite has been around for a while, so there‚Äôs plenty of legacy code. Although aggravating for the truly experienced, I find studying it to be valuable. Like a glimpse of code from a bygone era. The OOP principles are so present, not yet abstracted to the point of dependency pasta. If only I didn‚Äôt have to write my own date conversion functions üò¢

text.content: Final Thoughts

rich_text.plain_text: Final Thoughts

text.content: More to come, that‚Äôs for sure. I‚Äôm hoping to attach articles that have helped me, review Netsuite‚Äôs official courses (which I have yet to take), and attach some code snippets of cool stuff I‚Äôve found. Until then, cya!

text.content: Receiving Email through EmailJS
Overview

rich_text.plain_text: Overview

text.content: The first time I built a portfolio (a few years ago), I shied away from adding mail server functionality to my app. I incorrectly assumed that using a frontend framework like React (as opposed to Express, Nest, etc) would make it impossible to securely connect to an email service. Turns out I was wrong! (Not the first time)

rich_text.plain_text: The first time I built a portfolio (a few years ago), I shied away from adding mail server functionality to my app. I incorrectly assumed that using a frontend framework like React (as opposed to Express, Nest, etc) would make it impossible to securely connect to an email service. Turns out I was wrong! (Not the first time)

text.content: What is EmailJS?

rich_text.plain_text: What is EmailJS?

text.content: EmailJS is a service that allows you to send emails directly from your JavaScript code without the need for a backend server. It leverages email templates and a straightforward API that can pretty much be tossed into any application.

rich_text.plain_text: EmailJS is a service that allows you to send emails directly from your JavaScript code without the need for a backend server. It leverages email templates and a straightforward API that can pretty much be tossed into any application.

The next step is to write a React (or Svelte, Vue, etc) component that can consume the data in the exported format. As an example, I‚Äôll attach my component (Svelte) below:

Go Back

{data.note.icon} {data.note.title}

Tags
{#each data.note.tags as tag} {tag} {/each}
Date Created
{new Date(data.note.dateCreated).toLocaleDateString()}
{#each data.note.blocks as block} {@html renderBlock(block)} {/each}
